An integral domain $R$ satisfying the conditions that every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ can be uniquely written, up to associatedness and order, as a product of irreducible elements, and every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ is a product of prime elements. An element of a unique factorization domain is irreducible if and only if it is prime.
System of Generators of an Ideal

Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an ideal of a ring $R$. A family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of elements in $\mathfrak{a}$ is called a system of generators of $\mathfrak{a}$ if $\mathfrak{a}=\sum_{i \in I} R a_{i}$, i.e., if $\mathfrak{a}$ coincides with the ideal generated by the family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$.

Does the concept of a/an Factorial ring/unique factorization domain need to be defined for a definition of a/an System of Generators of an Ideal to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a System of Generators of an Ideal is defined in the context of any ring $R$, where an ideal $\mathfrak{a}$ of $R$ can be expressed as the sum of the ideals generated by a family of elements within $\mathfrak{a}$. This definition does not require $R$ to have any specific properties related to factorization, such as being a unique factorization domain or a factorial ring.

On the other hand, a Factorial Ring or Unique Factorization Domain (UFD) is a specific type of integral domain where every non-zero non-unit element can be uniquely factored into irreducibles, which are also primes. This property pertains to the factorization of elements within the ring, not to the structure of ideals or their generators.

Therefore, the definition and understanding of a System of Generators of an Ideal do not depend on the ring $R$ being a UFD. The concept of generators of an ideal is applicable in any ring, regardless of whether it has unique factorization properties or not.
